# **Rising Temperature**

## Write an SQL query to find all dates' Ids with higher temperatures compared to its previous dates (yesterday).

### Table Schema
| Column | Type | Description |
|---|---|---|
| id | INTEGER | Primary Key |
| recordDate | DATE | Date |
| temperature | INTEGER | Temp |

### Example

**Input:**
```
**Weather**
+----+------------+-------------+
| id | recordDate | temperature |
+----+------------+-------------+
| 1  | 2015-01-01 | 10          |
| 2  | 2015-01-02 | 25          |
| 3  | 2015-01-03 | 20          |
| 4  | 2015-01-04 | 30          |
+----+------------+-------------+
```

**Expected Output:**
```
+----+
| id |
+----+
| 2  |
| 4  |
+----+
```

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE Weather (id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, recordDate DATE, temperature INTEGER); INSERT INTO Weather (id, recordDate, temperature) VALUES (1, '2015-01-01', 10), (2, '2015-01-02', 25), (3, '2015-01-03', 20), (4, '2015-01-04', 30);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT w1.id FROM Weather w1 JOIN Weather w2 ON julianday(w1.recordDate) - julianday(w2.recordDate) = 1 WHERE w1.temperature > w2.temperature;
